questions.text: A man is referred for fever and agitation for the past 4 days. Examination reveals a disoriented man who is unable to swallow water due to involuntary inspiratory muscle spasms of the pharynx.  He had been bitten by a dog 3 months ago but was not treated. What genus does the causative organism of this condition belong to?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with hydrophobia and a history of an untreated dog bite is highly suggestive of rabies. The causative virus belongs to the genus Lyssavirus.  

Rabies virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Rhabdoviridae. This family has 3 genera:

  • Lyssavirus
  • Vesiculovirus
  • Ephemerovirus

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the fixed virus of rabies?

choices.text: Does not multiply in extra neural tissues

questions.solution:
The fixed virus has a short incubation period.

There are 2 types of rabies viruses:

Fixed virus Street virus 

Isolated after several intracerebral passages in rabbits

Isolated from naturally occurring cases of rabies

Short, fixed, and reproducible incubation period of 6 to 7 days

 The incubation period is long and highly variable between 1 to 12 weeks

Does not form Negri bodies or multiply in extraneural tissues

 Forms Negri bodies and multiplies in extraneural tissues

Used in the preparation of live-attenuated anti-rabies vaccine

 It is the primary cause of rabies disease

questions.text: Which of the following does not lead to the transmission of rabies to humans?

choices.text: Nibbling by an infected animal on abraded skin
Direct contact of infected saliva with the mucosa
Ingestion of raw meat of infected animal

questions.solution:
Ingestion of the raw meat of the infected animal does not lead to the transmission of rabies.

Mammals like dogs and bats are important animal sources. The important modes of transmission of rabies are as follows:

  • Scratches or deep bites
  • Exposure of infected saliva to intact mucosa or fresh skin wounds

Human–to–human transmission through bites has never been confirmed.

questions.text: You have witnessed your neighbor being bitten by a rabid dog. You should advise him to wash the wound with soap and water for a minimum of:
questions.solution:
Following dog bites, the bite wound should be washed with soap under running tap water for 15 minutes.

Local treatment of the bite wound is essential for the prevention of rabies and can reduce the infection rate by up to 80%. The following steps must be followed:

  • Cleansing: Washing under running water with soap or irrigation with a catheter in case of deep wounds
  • Chemical agent: Alcohol or tincture /0.01% aqueous solution of iodine or povidone-iodine is effective for inactivation of residual virus
  • Suturing: Must be done only following 24-48 hours if necessary, under the cover of rabies immunoglobulin locally and minimal stitches
  • Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures when indicated

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was bitten by a suspected rabid dog . On examination, there are minor scratches and abrasions without bleeding. Which of the following is true about the category and management of the wound?

choices.text: Category II - Local treatment of wound with povidone and follow up
Category III - Local treatment of wound and give ARV and antibiotics
Category II - Local treatment of wound and give ARV
Category III - Give ARV and anti-rabies immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
Minor scratches and abrasions without bleeding are classified under category II wounds. Category II wounds are managed by immediate local treatment of wound and vaccination (ARV).

Antibiotics are not required in case of minor scratches and abrasions.

questions.text: A public health worker was brought with multiple transdermal dog bites. He tells you that he had received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Wound washing and ARV with half dose of RIG
Wound treatment and ARV; RIG is not required

questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario of a patient with multiple transdermal dog bites would be categorised under category III. As the patient received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago, his line of management includes the following:
  1. Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 minutes and application of antiseptic
  2. Anti-rabies vaccine 2 doses on day 0 and day 3, with either intradermal vaccine(0.1ml, 1 site) or intramuscular vaccine(1 vial, 1site).
There is no requirement for Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), if previous pre-exposure prophylaxis or post exposure prophylaxis documentation is available. If documentation of PEP or PrEP is unavailable, patient should be treated as fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had received a full course rabies vaccine taken in December 2018. His pet dog which has been fully vaccinated now (November 2019) bit him on the toe. Bleeding was present at the site of the bite. What would be the line of treatment?
questions.solution:
This boy should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows:

  • Category I: Wound treatment only
  • Category II/ III:
    • Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 min and apply antiseptic
    • Receive Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) 2 doses ID (0.1 ml, 1 site)/ 2 doses IM (1 VIAL, 1 site) on days 0 and 3.

*Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals alone, doesn't play a significant role in determining the initiation of prophylaxis in humans.

The incubation period of yellow fever is 3–6 days.

questions.text: According to the International Health Regulations, an Aedes aegypti index of which of the following must be maintained to achieve zero risk of spread of yellow fever?
questions.solution:
The Aedes aegypti index should be < 1% in endemic areas to achieve zero risk of spread of yellow fever.

The Aedes aegypti index is a type of house index. It refers to the percentage of houses and premises in a limited well-defined area with actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae.

questions.text: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination is she eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.

The 17D vaccine for yellow fever is given subcutaneously. Unvaccinated people are required to remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

questions.text: Which of the following is the yellow fever reference center in India?
questions.solution:
The reference centers for yellow fever in India are as follows:

  • Central Research Institute, Kasauli
  • National Institute of Virology, Pune

questions.text: An outbreak of Kyasanur forest disease occurred among a group of forest officers in Karnataka. Which of the following vectors should be targeted to prevent the further spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is transmitted by the bite of infective hard ticks of Haemaphysalis species. Hence, control of ticks must be done to prevent spread of the disease.

KFD is a hemorrhagic febrile disease caused by a flavivirus. Man is an incidental dead-end host in the life cycle of the vector (hard tick). Small mammals like rodents and squirrels are the reservoirs while monkeys serve as the amplifier hosts. KFD is endemic in 4 districts of Karnataka (Shimoga, North Kannada, South Kannada, Chikmagalur).

The incubation period is between 3 to 8 days. The disease presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, myalgia. In severe cases, gastrointestinal disturbances and hemorrhages from the nose, gums, stomach, and intestine may occur. The case fatality rate is 5 to 10%.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route?
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons).  The basic cycles of transmission are:

 (a)Pig → Mosquito  → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which following is false about Japanese encephalitis?

choices.text: Man is the incidental dead-end host
Culicines act as vectors for this condition
It is caused by a group B arbovirus

questions.solution:
The incubation period of Japanese encephalitis (JE) in man following a mosquito bite is 5-15 days.

JE is mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus). It is transmitted by Culex (culicine) mosquitoes mainly C.tritaeniorhynchus and C.vishnui. Ardeid birds (herons) are the reservoirs while pigs are the amplifier hosts. Man is an incidental dead-end host. Man-to-man transmission has not been recorded.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Japanese encephalitis?

choices.text: SA-14-14-2 strain vaccine is commonly used
Diagnosis is confirmed by CSF culture
Patients usually recover without any sequelae

questions.solution:
SA-14-14-2 strain vaccine is used for the prevention of Japanese encephalitis (JE).

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. Most individuals develop subclinical infection. 

The course of disease in man divided into 3 stages:

  • Prodromal stage - fever, headache, gastrointestinal disturbances, lethargy, and malaise
  • Acute encephalitic stage - high-grade fever, nuchal rigidity, convulsions, signs of raised intracranial pressure, paralysis, altered sensorium 
  • Late-stage and sequelae -  neurological or psychiatric sequelae seen in up to 50% of survivors

Diagnosis is serological, using blood or CSF samples. The virus rarely grows in culture. The case fatality rate varies between 20-40%. There are 3 types of JE vaccines available:

  • Nakayama or Beijing strain - purified inactivated vaccine
  • Beijing P-3 strain - inactivated vaccine
  • SA-14-14-2 - live attenuated vaccine

Note: Killed JE vaccines (Inactivated SA 14-14-2 cell culture-derived and inactivated Vero cell culture-derived) are gradually replacing live attenuated vaccines.  According to the national immunisation schedule, both live attenuated, killed-inactivated vaccines are now used for vaccination against the JE virus.

questions.text: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus.

Nipah virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus. It is a zoonotic virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family.

The clinical manifestations include asymptomatic subclinical infection, acute respiratory infection, and fatal encephalitis. There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.

Nipah virus is on the WHO list of Blueprint priority diseases.
